 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2165-11-11**] 12:05 AM

   - Following ID recs, and Plastics and Surgery recs.
   - Zosyn, Vanc and Clinda started; BCx grew back GPC in pairs, chains,

   Physical Examination
   Gen: Somnolent, intermittently apneic, rousable to loud voice
   HEENT: Pupils pinpoint = 2mm, reactive; crusting lesions on R eyebrow,
   R upper lip and R anterior neck; symmetric; MMM
   PULM: CTAB b/l except mild crackles L base posteriorly without
   wheeze/rale/ronchi
   CV: Tachycardia, clear S1/S2 without m/g, no audible rub
   Abd: Mildly distended, +BS, soft, NT, no palpable masses; mild erythema
   in lower abdomen along hypogastrum, increased erythema L flank
   Back: No open lesions; 1-2mm papular lesions diffusely
   GU: Erythematous, mildly TTP scrotum, prepuce with mild erythema and
   swelling inferiorly
   Ext: WWP, lower extremity size asymmetry; LLE with diffuse erythema -
   TTP from knee inferiourly; RLE with diffuse erythema; 4x3cm poorly
   healing ulcer R foot base with white/green lesion 1x1.5 medially.
   Skin: With diffuse rash as above on back/chest and forehead (stated to
   be x 3 weeks per girlfriend); additionally with several shallow/dry
   ulcerations on L hand with adjacent pustules (not open)
   Neuro: Sedated, moving all extremities
   Labs / Radiology
                            [**2165-11-10**]  11:00 PM
   TropT
   <0.01
   Other labs: CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:294/15/<0.01, ALT / AST:213/125, Alk
   Phos / T Bili:60/0.3, Albumin:2.0 g/dL, LDH:1209 IU/L
   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M, recently diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosupressed on Decadron
   x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days with nonhealing
   ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. With
   involvement of scrotum, could be polymycrobial origin, though no e/o
   crepitus as this point to suspect Fournier's; UA neg. Does not have
   significant pain distally, but given neuropathy, may be poor indicator
   of disease severity. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to be
   tachycardic. Afebrile.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Unasyn and
   Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone) at 250cc/hr for 1L
   - Appreciate surgery, ID, and plastics c/s and will f/u recs
   - Wound care consult for R foot, podiatry c/s
   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures, CXR
   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today?
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Will continue on Decadron PRN
   - Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   # Decreased RR: Likely [**2-23**] over medication with dilaudid and Darvocet,
   though patient confirms these are both his home doses. Adequate RR O/N.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - Darvocet PRN with holding parameters
   - Narcan PRN
   # R foot ulcer: Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services
   at home.
   - Appreciate Plastics inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Will obtain CT of foot to assess for OM.
   - Podiatry c/s
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - wound culture
   # L-spine lymphoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.
   Unclear how dx, states followed by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On
   decadron x 6 weeks for ?stenosis or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records
   - Will slightly wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse
   infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Diffuse rash: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Most c/w
   folliculitis.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial overgrowth since the decadron.
   - Monitor
   PPx: bowel regimen PRN, hold pneumboots, consider heparin SC in AM
   FEN: IVF x 4L, replete PRN, clears
   Access: PIV x 2. R SCL CVL
   Code Status:  FULL (confirmed on admission)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **], girlfriend, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2840**] (home) or [**0-0-**]
   (cell)
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2165-11-10**] 08:36 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2165-11-10**] 08:38 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-11-11**] 12:05 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosuppressed on Decadron for 3 weeks, presenting with b/l LE cellulitis and CP, and a non-healing ulcer on his R foot for 7 years. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, likely related to the chronic RLE ulcer and polymyositis in the setting of immunosuppression. He has a history of MRSA infection in his R foot and currently has a diffuse rash on his back, anterior chest wall, and forehead, likely due to bacterial overgrowth since starting Decadron.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Tmax: 37.1°C
* Tcurrent: 36.9°C
* HR: 113 bpm
* BP: 115/65 mmHg
* RR: 10 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 95%
* CVP: 1 mmHg

The patient is receiving antibiotics for potential polymicrobial infection, and IV fluids are being administered to match CVP. He is also receiving insulin and other medications as needed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing septic shock due to his immunosuppressed state and chronic infections.
2. Pericarditis: The patient's chest pain may be related to pericarditis, which could be infectious, neoplastic, or cardiovascular in origin.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to multiple etiologies, including systemic inflammatory response, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.
4. Decreased RR: The patient's decreased respiratory rate may be due to over-medication with Dilaudid and Darvocet.
5. R foot ulcer: The patient's R foot ulcer may become infected or worsen due to poor wound care and chronic immunosuppression.
6. L-spine lymphoma: The patient's lymphoma may be affecting his spinal cord, leading to neurological symptoms.
7. Neurogenic Bladder: The patient's Foley catheter may not be functioning properly, leading to urinary retention or incontinence.
8. Diffuse rash: The patient's diffuse rash may worsen due to bacterial overgrowth or allergic reactions to medications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics for potential polymicrobial infection.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust treatment as needed.
3. Obtain a CT scan of the foot to assess for osteomyelitis.
4. Consult with a wound care specialist and podiatry to optimize wound care.
5. Discuss the patient's L-spine lymphoma with his neurologist and obtain records.
6. Wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse infection.
7. Monitor the patient's neurogenic bladder and adjust treatment as needed.
8. Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of lymphoma and immunosuppression on Decadron for the past three weeks. He presents with bilateral lower extremity cellulitis and chronic right lower extremity ulcer with non-healing wounds. The patient has been experiencing tachycardia, elevated bands, and positive Gram stain on blood culture, consistent with sepsis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic condition may worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ failure and increased mortality.
2. Pericarditis: The patient's chest pain may be related to pericarditis, which can lead to cardiac tamponade and cardiac arrest if not properly managed.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and decreased respiratory rate may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
4. Renal failure: The patient's septic condition and potential polymicrobial infection may lead to renal failure if not properly managed.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's immunosuppression and lymphoma diagnosis may increase his risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
6. Wound infection: The patient's chronic right lower extremity ulcer may become infected, leading to further complications and increased risk of amputation.
7. Fungal infection: The patient's immunosuppression and presence of chronic wounds may increase his risk of developing fungal infections, such as candidemia or aspergillosis.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and potential pericarditis may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.

To mitigate these risks, the patient should receive aggressive management of his septic condition, including administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. The patient's wounds should be properly cleaned and dressed to prevent infection, and the patient should be monitored for signs of respiratory, renal, and neurological compromise.

   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M, recently diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosupressed on Decadron
   x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days with nonhealing
   ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. Also
   considering fungal infection. With involvement of scrotum, could be
   polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to suspect
   Fournier's. UA neg. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to be
   tachycardic. Afebrile.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Unasyn and
   Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone) at 250cc/hr for 1L
   - Appreciate surgery, ID, and plastics c/s and will f/u recs

   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL

   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock

   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today?
   - Cardiology recs

   colcicine)
   - Will continue on Decadron PRN
   - Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above

   though patient confirms these are both his home doses. Adequate RR O/N.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - Darvocet PRN with holding parameters
   - Narcan PRN
   # R foot ulcer: Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services
   at home.
   - Appreciate Plastics inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Will obtain CT of foot to assess for OM.
   - Podiatry c/s
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - wound culture
   # L-spine lymphoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.
   Unclear how dx, states followed by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On
   decadron x 6 weeks for ?stenosis or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of lymphoma, who presented to the emergency department with sepsis, bilateral lower extremity cellulitis, and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. He has been on Decadron for three weeks and has a history of MRSA infection in his right foot. He was started on antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Unasyn, and Clindamycin, and is being monitored for sepsis and potential complications.

Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to his chronic right lower extremity ulcer, which has developed cellulitis and polymyositis in the setting of immunosuppression on Decadron.
2. Pericarditis: The patient's chest pain is likely related to pericarditis, which may be infectious, neoplastic, or cardiovascular in origin.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely due to multiple etiologies, including systemic inflammatory response, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.
4. Bandemia: The patient's bandemia is likely due to cellulitis or polymyositis, although other possible sources include urine, pleural effusion, or pericardial effusion.
5. Decreased Respiratory Rate: The patient's decreased respiratory rate is likely due to over-medication with Dilaudid and Darvocet.
6. Right Foot Ulcer: The patient's right foot ulcer appears clean at the base with clear fluid and is being managed with antibiotics and wound care.
7. L-Spine Lymphoma: The patient has a history of lymphoma in his lower spine, which is being managed with steroids and may require further discussion with his neurologist.
8. Neurogenic Bladder: The patient has a neurogenic bladder and is being managed with oxybutynin and a Foley catheter.
9. Diffuse Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash on his back, anterior chest wall, and forehead, which is likely due to folliculitis or bacterial overgrowth.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his sepsis and immunosuppression.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient is at risk for cardiac complications, including pericarditis, tamponade, and cardiovascular instability.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient is at risk for respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient is at risk for neurological complications, including seizures and cerebral edema.
5. Wound Complications: The patient is at risk for wound complications, including infection and delayed healing.

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of b/l LE cellulitis and CP, with a non-healing ulcer on his R foot for 7 years. He is immunosuppressed due to steroid treatment for a L-spine lymphoma diagnosis 6 weeks ago. The patient has a history of MRSA infection in his R foot and is currently being treated with Vancomycin, Unasyn, and Clindamycin for a potential polymicrobial infection. He also has chest pain and is being treated for suspected pericarditis or myositis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's immunosuppressed state and polymicrobial infection make him prone to septic shock, which could lead to multi-organ failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tachypnea and possible pneumonia could lead to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's chest pain and elevated BNP could indicate cardiac complications such as pericarditis or myositis, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or even cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of lymphoma and immunosuppression make him prone to neurological complications such as seizures or cerebral edema.
5. Wound Complications: The patient's non-healing ulcer on his R foot could lead to further complications such as infection, necrosis, or amputation.
6. Infection-related Complications: The patient's polymicrobial infection could lead to complications such as sepsis, bacteremia, or endocarditis.
7. Steroid-related Complications: The patient's steroid treatment for his lymphoma could lead to complications such as adrenal insufficiency, osteoporosis, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. Also
   considering sinusitis and fungal infection (considering

   could be polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to
   suspect Fournier's. UA neg. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to
   be tachycardic. Afebrile.

   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as

   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of lymphoma, immunosuppressed on Decadron for the past 3 weeks, presenting with bilateral lower extremity cellulitis and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, likely related to his chronic right lower extremity ulcer, and is being treated with vancomycin, Unasyn, and Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.8°F)
* Heart rate: 113 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 115/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 10 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Central venous pressure: 1 mmHg

The patient has a diffuse rash on his back, anterior chest wall, and forehead, which is likely bacterial overgrowth related to his immunosuppressed state. He also has a 4x3 cm poorly healing ulcer on his right foot base with a white/green lesion.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Anaerobic GPC in pairs and chains on blood culture
* Elevated lactate level (2.8 at 12 am)
* Elevated creatine kinase (CK) level (87)
* Elevated troponin-T level (<0.01)
* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) with bandemia

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Continuation of vancomycin, Unasyn, and Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection
* IV fluid administration with normal saline at 250cc/hr for 1L
* Wound care consult for right foot ulcer
* Podiatry consult
* Daily wet-to-dry dressing changes
* Follow-up wound culture and biopsy
* Stress dose steroids if septic shock develops
* Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis
* Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN, and Percocet
* TSH check to rule out hypothyroidism

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction or failure
* Wound infection or cellulitis
* Pericarditis or myocarditis
* Respiratory failure
* Hypothyroidism
* Neurological complications due to lymphoma or immunosuppression
* Gastrointestinal complications due to immunosuppression or sepsis
* Renal failure due to sepsis or immunosuppression

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M, recently diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosupressed on Decadron
   x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days with nonhealing
   ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. Also
   considering sinusitis and fungal infection (considering
   immunosuppression and skin impairment). With involvement of scrotum,
   could be polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to
   suspect Fournier's. UA neg. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to
   be tachycardic. Afebrile.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Unasyn and
   Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone) at 250cc/hr for 1L
   - Appreciate surgery, ID, and plastics c/s and will f/u recs
   - Wound care consult for R foot, podiatry c/s
   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures, CXR
   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock
   - Warm pack to right arm
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today?
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Will continue on Decadron PRN
   - Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN, percocet
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   #Sinusitis:
   -[**Doctor First Name **]
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   # Decreased RR: Likely [**2-23**] over medication with dilaudid and Darvocet,
   though patient confirms these are both his home doses. Adequate RR O/N.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - Darvocet PRN with holding parameters
   - Narcan PRN
   # R foot ulcer: Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services
   at home.
   - Appreciate Plastics inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Will obtain CT of foot to assess for OM.
   - Podiatry c/s
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - f/u wound culture/biopsy
   # L-spine lymphoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.
   Unclear how dx, states followed by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On
   decadron x 6 weeks for ?stenosis or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records
   - Will slightly wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse
   infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Diffuse rash: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Most c/w
   folliculitis.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial overgrowth since the decadron
   although could be fungal related.
   -          Monitor
   -          Consult derm per plastics
   PPx: bowel regimen PRN, hold pneumboots, consider heparin SC in AM
   FEN: IVF x 4L, replete PRN, clears

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of lymphoma, immunosuppressed on Decadron for three weeks, who presented to the emergency department with bilateral lower extremity cellulitis and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. He has been diagnosed with sepsis and is being treated with antibiotics. He also has a chronic right lower extremity ulcer with resulting cellulitis and polymyositis. He is experiencing tachycardia, chest pain, and a diffuse rash.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing septic shock due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of multiple potential sources of infection.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and chest pain may be indicative of cardiac involvement, potentially due to pericarditis, myositis, or cardiac tamponade.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's decreased respiratory rate may be due to overmedication or respiratory depression, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of lymphoma and immunosuppression may increase his risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or meningitis.
5. Wound complications: The patient's chronic right lower extremity ulcer is at risk of further infection and potential amputation.
6. Renal complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state and sepsis may increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state and sepsis may increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis or inflammatory bowel disease.
8. Infections: The patient's immunosuppressed state and multiple potential sources of infection make him at risk of developing a wide range of infections, including bacterial, fungal, and viral infections.
9. Bleeding complications: The patient's immunosuppressed state and anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk of bleeding complications, such as epistaxis or gastrointestinal bleeding.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's sepsis, cardiac, respiratory, neurological, wound, renal, gastrointestinal, and infectious complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of lymphoma, who is immunosuppressed and has been taking Decadron for the past three weeks. He presented to the emergency department with tachycardia, elevated bands, and positive Gram stain on blood culture, consistent with sepsis. The patient has a history of MRSA infection in his right foot and has a chronic non-healing ulcer on his right foot.

The patient is currently receiving antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Zosyn, and Clindamycin, and is being treated for sepsis. He is also receiving IV fluids and has a central venous catheter (CVP) in place.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.
2. Pericarditis: The patient has elevated BNP levels, which could be indicative of a myositic process, and is at risk for pericarditis.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely due to multiple etiologies, including systemic inflammatory response, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.
4. Decreased Respiratory Rate: The patient's decreased respiratory rate may be due to overmedication with Dilaudid and Darvocet.
5. Transaminitis: The patient has moderate elevation of liver function tests, which may be due to infection or decreased perfusion related to sepsis or medication-induced.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is taking high doses of levothyroxine, which could exacerbate his tachycardia.
7. Chronic Wound on Right Foot: The patient has a chronic non-healing ulcer on his right foot, which is at risk for infection and may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. L-Spine Lymphoma: The patient has a history of lymphoma in his lumbar spine, which is being treated with steroids.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Septic shock: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.
2. Pericarditis: The patient is at risk for pericarditis due to his elevated BNP levels and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.
3. Cardiac tamponade: The patient is at risk for cardiac tamponade due to the presence of a pericardial effusion.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his decreased respiratory rate and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient is at risk for hepatic failure due to his transaminitis and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.
6. Neurological complications: The patient is at risk for neurological complications due to his history of lymphoma and the presence of a chronic wound on his right foot.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is recommended that he continue to receive antibiotics, IV fluids, and pain management. He should also be closely monitored for signs of septic shock, pericarditis, and cardiac tamponade.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a multi-lumen central venous catheter (CVC) placed and verified. The patient is receiving antibiotics, including Zosyn, Vanc, and Clinda, and has undergone fluid resuscitation to match central venous pressure (CVP). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 113 bpm, and blood pressure of 115/65 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 95%. The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's critical condition, and the patient is not assessed for peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, or other systems.

The patient has undergone a chest computed tomography (CT) scan, which is pending report. The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, creatine kinase (CK), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating possible cardiac injury. The patient's liver enzymes, including alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), are elevated, indicating possible liver injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin-T levels and cardiac enzymes suggest possible cardiac injury. This could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's need for oxygen therapy and potential respiratory failure could lead to respiratory arrest or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Infection: The patient's antibiotic treatment and possible bacterial sepsis could lead to septic shock, multi-organ failure, or death.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulant medications and possible bleeding diathesis could lead to bleeding complications, including hemorrhage or hematoma.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes could lead to liver failure or encephalopathy.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's fluid resuscitation and potential sepsis could lead to acute kidney injury or failure.
7. Neurologic complications: The patient's possible cardiac or respiratory failure could lead to neurologic complications, including stroke, seizures, or coma.

   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M, immunosupressed on Decadron x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis
   and CP several days with nonhealing ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Cellulitis: Very concerning given extent and seemingly rapid
   progression over last 24 hours.  Does have h/o MRSA infection in R
   foot.  No h/o cellulitis.  Also concerning given immunosupression on
   Decadron x 3 weeks.  With involvement of scrotum, could be
   polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to suspect
   Fournier's.  Does not have significant pain distally, but given
   neuropathy, may be poor indicator of disease severity.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Unasyn and
   Clindamycin for potential polymicrobial infection
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone)
   - Surgery consult given extent of cellulitis, ?polymyositis
   - Wound care consult for R foot
   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18g
   - Follow-up all cultures
   - ID consult in AM
   - Plastics consult for R foot
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  Does have elevated
   BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out ACS,
   though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as pericarditis.
   - ROMI
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Echo in AM
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Will continue on Decadron PRN
   - Pain management with Darvocet
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response, infection with signficant bandemia
   (?bacteremia), pain and pericarditis.  No evidence of tamponade on
   bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this point.  Does have drug abuse
   h/o but none presently, will send tox screen anyway.  Not on beta
   blocker so unlikely to be having rebound.  Does have h/o
   hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Obtain CVP s/p CVL placement
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain
   - Tox screen
   - TSH
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   # Decreased RR: Likely [**2-23**] over medication with dilaudid and Darvocet,
   though patient confirms these are both his home doses.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - Darvocet PRN with holding parameters
   - Narcan PRN
   # R foot ulcer: Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services
   at home.
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Plastics / wound consult
   - daily dressing changes & wound culture
   # L-spine lymphoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.
   Unclear how dx, states followed by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On
   decadron x 6 weeks for ?stenosis or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records
   - Will slightly wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse
   infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Diffuse rash: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Most c/w
   folliculitis.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial overgrowth since the decadron.
   - Monitor
   PPx: bowel regimen PRN, hold pneumboots, consider heparin SC in AM
   FEN: IVF x 4L, replete PRN, clears
   Access: PIV x 2. will place CVL
   Code Status:  FULL (confirmed on admission)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old male who is immunosuppressed due to Decadron therapy for 3 weeks. He has a history of MRSA infection in his right foot and is currently experiencing bilateral lower extremity (LE) cellulitis with a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management of his condition.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.8°F)
* Heart rate: 113 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 115/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 10 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Somnolent, intermittently apneic, and rousable to loud voice
* Pinpoint pupils, reactive to light
* Crusting lesions on the right eyebrow, upper lip, and anterior neck
* Mildly distended abdomen with bowel sounds, soft and non-tender
* Erythematous, mildly tender scrotum and prepuce with swelling inferiorly
* Lower extremity size asymmetry, with diffuse erythema on the left leg from knee inferiorly
* A 4x3 cm poorly healing ulcer on the right foot base with white/green lesion medially

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Creatine kinase (CK) and CKMB: 294/15
* Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 1209 IU/L
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 213/125
* Alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos) and total bilirubin (T Bili): 60/0.3
* Albumin: 2.0 g/dL

The patient's diagnosis includes:

* Bilateral LE cellulitis with a non-healing ulcer on the right foot
* Polymicrobial infection (possibility of Fournier's)
* Pericarditis (likely) or myositis
* Tachycardia (likely multiple etiologies)
* Bandemia (likely from cellulitis or polymyositis)
* Decreased respiratory rate (likely due to medication)
* Neurogenic bladder
* Diffuse rash (likely bacterial overgrowth)

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue Vancomycin, Unasyn, and Clindamycin for polymicrobial infection
* Continue IV fluids with normal saline (avoiding lactated Ringer's solution)
* Surgery consult for extent of cellulitis and potential polymyositis
* Wound care consult for right foot
* Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation
* Follow-up all cultures
* ID consult in the morning
* Plastics consult for right foot
* Continue Decadron PRN
* Pain management with Darvocet
* Tox screen
* TSH

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of cellulitis and polymicrobial infection
* Development of septic shock
* Pericarditis and myositis complications
* Tachycardia and decreased respiratory rate complications
* Neurogenic bladder complications
* Diffuse rash complications
* Wound infection and dehiscence
* Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures, CXR
   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock
   - Warm pack to right arm
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI by cardiac enzymes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN, percocet
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   # Decreased RR: Likely [**2-23**] over medication with dilaudid and Darvocet,
   though patient confirms these are both his home doses. Adequate RR O/N.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - Darvocet PRN with holding parameters
   #Transaminitis: Moderate elevation c/w possible infection or decreased
   perfusion related to sepsis or medication induced.
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   #Hypothyroidism: TSH <0.02. Reports taking high dose of levothyroxine
   (175mcg) qday which could exacerbate tachycardia.
   -Clarify home doses of thyroid medication
   -check free T4 and total T3.
   # R foot ulcer: Chronic issue over past 7yrs. Well known to
   plastics/surgery. Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services
   at home.
   - Appreciate Plastics inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Will obtain CT of foot to assess for OM.
   - Podiatry c/s
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - f/u wound culture/biopsy
   # L-spine lymphoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.
   Followed by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On decadron x 6 weeks for
   ?stenosis or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records
   - Will slightly wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse
   infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Diffuse rash: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Most c/w
   folliculitis.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial overgrowth since the decadron
   although could be fungal related.
   -          Monitor
   -          Consult derm per plastics
   PPx: bowel regimen PRN, hold pneumboots, consider heparin SC in AM
   FEN: IVF x 4L, replete PRN, clears
   Access: PIV x 2 (18,20). R SCL CVL
   Code Status:  FULL (confirmed on admission)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **], girlfriend, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2840**] (home) or [**0-0-**]
   (cell)

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient Summary:**

The patient is a 45-year-old male diagnosed with lymphoma, who presented to the emergency department with bilateral lower extremity cellulitis and chronic non-healing ulcer on his right foot. He has a history of immunosuppression on Decadron for the past 3 weeks and has been experiencing symptoms for several days. He was found to have sepsis, with a positive blood culture, and was treated with antibiotics. He also has a chronic rash on his back, anterior chest wall, and forehead, which is likely related to folliculitis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Sepsis:** The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and he continues to receive antibiotics. There is a risk of septic shock, and stress dose steroids may be necessary if septic physiology develops.
2. **Pericarditis:** The patient has elevated BNP levels, which could indicate a myositic process. He may have pericarditis, and further evaluation with a formal echo and cardiac enzymes is necessary.
3. **Tachycardia:** The patient's tachycardia may be due to multiple etiologies, including systemic inflammatory response, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis. He may require further evaluation to determine the underlying cause.
4. **Hypothyroidism:** The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is taking high doses of levothyroxine, which may exacerbate his tachycardia.
5. **Decreased Respiratory Rate:** The patient's decreased respiratory rate may be due to over-medication with dilaudid and Darvocet. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.
6. **Transaminitis:** The patient has moderate elevation of liver enzymes, which may be related to infection or decreased perfusion. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.
7. **Neurogenic Bladder:** The patient has a Foley catheter in place and is taking oxybutyin. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause of his neurogenic bladder.
8. **Diffuse Rash:** The patient has a diffuse rash on his back, anterior chest wall, and forehead, which is likely related to folliculitis. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.

**Assessment and Plan:**

The patient will continue to receive antibiotics and will have further evaluation with a formal echo, cardiac enzymes, and liver function tests. He will also have a CT scan of his foot to assess for osteomyelitis. He will require further management of his pain, anxiety, and hypothyroidism.

   45 yo M, recently diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosupressed on Decadron
   x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days with nonhealing
   ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. Also
   considering sinusitis and fungal infection (considering
   immunosuppression and skin impairment). With involvement of scrotum,
   could be polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to
   suspect Fournier's. UA neg. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to
   be tachycardic. Afebrile.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Zosyn and Clindamycin
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone) at 250cc/hr for 1L
   - Appreciate surgery, ID, and plastics c/s and will f/u recs
   - Wound care consult for R foot, podiatry c/s
   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures, CXR
   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock
   - Warm pack to right arm
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI by cardiac enzymes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN, percocet
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Darvocet for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of lymphoma, immunosuppressed on Decadron for 3 weeks, presenting with bilateral lower extremity cellulitis, chronic right lower extremity (RLE) ulcer, and possible polymyositis. He also has a history of MRSA infection in the RLE.

The patient's current condition is complicated by sepsis, tachycardia, and pericarditis. The source of infection is likely related to the chronic RLE ulcer, and possible polymyositis in the setting of immunosuppression.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated lactate levels (2.8 mmol/L)
* Elevated cardiac enzymes (CK 87 IU/L, CK-MB 15 IU/L, Troponin-T <0.01 ng/mL)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 213 IU/L, AST 125 IU/L, Alkaline phosphatase 60 IU/L, Total bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL)
* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) with bandemia

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Lymphoma
* Hypothyroidism
* Chronic RLE ulcer
* History of MRSA infection
* Immunosuppression on Decadron

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics (Vancomycin, Zosyn, Clindamycin) for sepsis and cellulitis
* IV fluids to maintain hydration and electrolyte balance
* Pain management with Darvocet, Morphine PRN, and Percocet
* Ibuprofen for pericarditis
* Wound care consultation for RLE ulcer
* Podiatry consultation for RLE ulcer
* CT scan of the foot to assess for osteomyelitis
* Dermatology consultation for diffuse rash
* Neurology consultation for L-spine lymphoma
* Stress dose steroids if septic shock develops

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Pericarditis-related tamponade
* Acute kidney injury due to sepsis or dehydration
* Respiratory failure due to sepsis or pneumonia
* Cardiovascular instability due to sepsis or pericarditis
* Neurological complications due to lymphoma or sepsis
* Wound complications due to cellulitis or osteomyelitis

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with sepsis, bacteremia, and multiple potential complications. The patient's condition is deteriorating, with ongoing respiratory distress, tachycardia, and fluid imbalance.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is likely to cause organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and coagulopathy.
2. Bacteremia-related complications: The patient's bacteremia can lead to endocarditis, osteomyelitis, and myo- or pericarditis, which can have serious consequences if left untreated.
3. Pericardial effusion and tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion can lead to cardiac tamponade, which can cause cardiovascular collapse and death.
4. Fluid imbalance and shock: The patient's fluid imbalance and tachycardia can lead to shock, which can further exacerbate their condition.
5. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities can indicate liver dysfunction, which can be a sign of severe sepsis.
6. Cellulitis and wound infections: The patient's cellulitis and wound infections can lead to further sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress can lead to respiratory failure, which can require mechanical ventilation.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and pericardial effusion can lead to cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.

In light of these potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring of the patient's condition, adjust their treatment plan as necessary, and consider consulting with specialists, such as infectious disease and cardiology, to optimize their care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with sepsis, respiratory distress, and potential complications. The patient's condition is unstable, and the note highlights several concerns that require close monitoring and management.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Pericarditis or myocarditis: The patient's tachycardia, chest pain, and diffuse EKG changes suggest a possible inflammatory process affecting the heart.
2. Pericardial effusion and tamponade: The patient's CVP elevation and tachycardia may be related to pericardial fluid accumulation, which can lead to cardiac tamponade.
3. Cellulitis or osteomyelitis: The patient's leg and scrotal erythema, as well as the presence of multiple eschars on fingers and hands, suggest a possible skin or soft tissue infection that may be spreading to deeper tissues.
4. Embolic events: The eschars on fingers and hands may indicate embolic events, such as endocarditis, which can lead to further complications.
5. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and the note mentions respiratory distress related to narcotics use.
6. Hypovolemia: The patient's tachycardia and CVP elevation may be related to hypovolemia, which can worsen with ongoing fluid loss.
7. LFT abnormalities: The patient's Alk Phos elevation and other LFT abnormalities suggest liver dysfunction, which may be related to sepsis or other underlying conditions.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of their condition, including:

1. Cardiac monitoring to assess for pericarditis or myocarditis
2. Serial LFTs to monitor liver function and potential for liver dysfunction
3. Fluid management to prevent hypovolemia and monitor CVP
4. Antibiotic therapy to address potential bacterial infections
5. Pain management to optimize respiratory status
6. Cardiac echo to assess for pericardial effusion and tamponade
7. Serial imaging to monitor for potential embolic events
8. Nutrition and glycemic control to optimize overall condition

The patient's code status is full code, indicating that all possible measures should be taken to save their life.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 24-hour old ICU patient with a complex medical condition. The patient has a large ulcer on the right foot, which is likely to be osteomyelitis due to exposed bone and gas seen extending along the fifth metatarsal shaft. The patient has also developed esophagitis and thrush, which is being treated with antifungal medication.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 106 bpm, and blood pressure of 118/65 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with an SpO2 of 92% and a respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate levels, which may indicate sepsis or infection. The patient's kidney function is also impaired, with elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.

The patient's medical history is significant for a lumbar lipoma, and the patient is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin sodium. The patient has also been prescribed morphine for breakthrough pain and has been given antifungal medication for esophagitis and thrush.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis or septic shock due to the presence of osteomyelitis and gas in the soft tissues of the foot.
2. Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying lung disease and the risk of aspiration pneumonia.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to the patient's underlying cardiac condition and the risk of electrolyte imbalances.
4. Renal failure due to the patient's impaired kidney function and the risk of further injury from nephrotoxic medications.
5. Infection or sepsis due to the patient's compromised immune system and the risk of secondary infections.
6. Worsening of the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as the lumbar lipoma, which could lead to further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M, recently diagnosed with lymphoma, immunosupressed on Decadron
   x 3 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days with nonhealing
   ulcer on R foot x 7 years.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and +GS
   on blood culture c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ hypoperfusion. Source
   of infection most likely related to patient
s chronic RLE ulcer with
   resulting cellulitis/polymyositis in setting of immunosupression on
   Decadron for past 3 weeks and given h/o MRSA infection in R foot. Also
   considering sinusitis and fungal infection (considering
   immunosuppression and skin impairment). With involvement of scrotum,
   could be polymycrobial origin, though no e/o crepitus as this point to
   suspect Fournier's. UA neg. CVP about >10. MAP >65. Yet pt continues to
   be tachycardic. Afebrile.
   - Continue Vancomycin (slowly given RM syndrome), Zosyn and Clindamycin
   - Continue IVF with NS (avoid LR given ceftriaxone) at 250cc/hr for 1L
   - Appreciate surgery, ID, and plastics c/s and will f/u recs
   - Wound care consult for R foot, podiatry c/s
   - Maintain adequate IV access for potential resuscitation, currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures, CXR
   - Check lactate
   - Stress dose steroids if septic shock
   - Warm pack to right arm
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious related but also consider
   neoplastic (metastatic lymphoma) or cardiovascular (CHF, MI). Does have
   elevated BNP which could be [**2-23**] myositic process.   Will also rule-out
   ACS, though EKG most consistent with diffuse process such as
   pericarditis. Bedside ECHO: normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%), mild MR, mod
   posterior pericardial effusion, no signs of tamponade).
   - ROMI by cardiac enzymes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today
   - Cardiology recs
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Pain management with [**Month/Day (2) **], Morphine PRN, percocet
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.  No
   evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in ED.  No e/o ACS at this
   point.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely to be having
   rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, will check TSH.
   - IVF, on 4L, will slow to 250cc
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - [**Month/Day (2) **] for pain, Morphine PRN
   - f/u TSH
   # R foot ulcer: Chronic issue over past 7yrs. Well known to
   plastics/surgery. Secondary to neuopathy from spina bifida and tethered
   cord syndrome. Appears clean at base with clear fluid.  VNA services at
   home.
   - Appreciate Plastics inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - Will obtain CT of foot to assess for OM.
   - Podiatry c/s
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - f/u wound culture/biopsy
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis vs polymyositis as above.  Other
   possible sources including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial
   effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   # Decreased RR: Likely [**2-23**] over medication with dilaudid and [**Month/Day (2) **],
   though patient confirms these are both his home doses. Adequate RR O/N.
   - Discontinue further dilaudid use
   - [**Month/Day (2) **] PRN with holding parameters
   #Transaminitis: Moderate elevation c/w possible infection or decreased
   perfusion related to sepsis or medication induced.
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   #Hypothyroidism: TSH <0.02. Reports taking high dose of levothyroxine
   (175mcg) qday which could exacerbate tachycardia.
   -Clarify home doses of thyroid medication
   -check free T4 and total T3.
   # L-spine Lipoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.  Followed
   by [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **].  On decadron x 6 weeks for ?stenosis
   or cord compression?.
   - Discuss with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**], obtain records
   - Will slightly wean steroids to 4mg TID given concern for diffuse
   infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Diffuse rash: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Most c/w
   folliculitis.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial overgrowth since the decadron
   although could be fungal related.
   -          Monitor
   -          Consult derm per plastics
   #Spina bifida/tethered cord syndrome: No new issues. Possible

   -Monitor for changes in neuron status

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of lymphoma, immunosuppression, and chronic right lower extremity (RLE) ulceration. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, cellulitis, and polymyositis. He has a large ulcer on his R foot with exposed bone and gas extending along the fifth metatarsal shaft. He has also developed a pericardial effusion and is at risk for septic shock. The patient's lactate level is elevated, and he has a moderate elevation in liver function tests (LFTs). He is also experiencing tachycardia, hypothyroidism, and a diffuse rash.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of cellulitis and polymyositis.
2. Pericarditis: The patient has developed a pericardial effusion, which may be infectious in origin or related to his lymphoma.
3. Wound infection: The patient's R foot ulcer is at risk for infection due to the presence of exposed bone and gas.
4. Osteomyelitis: The patient's R foot ulcer may be complicated by osteomyelitis, which could lead to further infection and tissue damage.
5. Fournier's gangrene: The patient's scrotal involvement could be a sign of Fournier's gangrene, a life-threatening infection of the perineum.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism could exacerbate his tachycardia and other symptoms.
7. Transaminitis: The patient's moderate elevation in LFTs could be related to infection, decreased perfusion, or medication-induced liver damage.
8. Neurogenic bladder: The patient's neurogenic bladder could lead to urinary retention and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and cellulitis.
2. Monitor the patient's lactate level and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Consider stress dose steroids if the patient develops septic shock.
4. Perform a formal ECHO to evaluate the patient's pericardial effusion.
5. Monitor the patient's wound for signs of infection and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Consider obtaining a wound culture and biopsy to determine the etiology of the patient's R foot ulcer.
7. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider consulting dermatology for further evaluation and management of the patient's diffuse rash.

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of spina bifida, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic right lower extremity (RLE) ulcer, who was recently diagnosed with a L-spine lipoma and has been taking Decadron for the past 5 weeks. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, b/l LE cellulitis, and CP, and was found to have Group G beta Strep bacteremia. He also has a R foot ulcer with osteomyelitis, and is at risk for fungemia.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, antifungals, and steroids, and has undergone arthrocentesis of the left knee. He has also been prescribed medications for pain management, including morphine, and has been advised to follow up with his primary care physician and specialists.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including organ failure and death.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's R foot ulcer with osteomyelitis is a serious infection that requires prompt treatment to prevent further complications, including amputation.
3. Fungemia: The patient is at risk for fungemia, which could lead to septicemia and death.
4. Pericarditis: The patient's pericarditis is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including cardiac tamponade and death.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and death.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including cognitive impairment and death.
7. Neurogenic bladder: The patient's neurogenic bladder is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including urinary tract infections and kidney damage.
8. HSV: The patient's HSV is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, including disseminated herpes and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust treatment as necessary.
3. Perform further imaging studies to evaluate the extent of the patient's osteomyelitis and pericarditis.
4. Consider surgical intervention to debride the patient's R foot ulcer and prevent further complications.
5. Monitor the patient's tachycardia and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Continue thyroid hormone replacement therapy as prescribed.
7. Monitor the patient's neurogenic bladder and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Continue antiviral therapy for HSV as prescribed.
9. Consider consulting with specialists, including infectious disease, cardiology, and neurology, to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old male with a complex medical history, including spina bifida, peripheral neuropathy, chronic RL foot ulcer, and recently diagnosed L-spine lipoma. He has been immunosuppressed on Decadron for 5 weeks and was recently admitted for sepsis.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Sepsis: The patient has Group G Streptococcal bacteremia, and his source of infection is likely related to his chronic RLE ulcer with resulting cellulitis in the setting of immunosuppression.
2. R foot ulcer/Osteomyelitis: The patient has a chronic ulcer at the proximal portion of the 5th metatarsal base and portion of the cuboid, which is likely to be osteomyelitis.
3. Odynophagia: The patient has reported having oral thrush and current odynophagia, which is being treated with fluconazole.
4. Knee Pain: The patient has reported increased R>L knee pain with decreased ROM, which may be related to septic arthritis.
5. Chest pain: The patient has reported chest pain, which is likely related to pericarditis or myositis.
6. Tachycardia: The patient has a tachycardic heart rate, which may be related to multiple etiologies including systemic inflammatory response, sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis.
7. Bandemia: The patient has elevated bandemia, which is likely related to cellulitis or polymyositis.
8. Decreased RR: The patient's respiratory rate has decreased, which may be related to over-medication with dilaudid and other medications.
9. Transaminitis: The patient has moderate elevation of liver enzymes, which may be related to infection or decreased perfusion.
10. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which may be exacerbated by his current medication regimen.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
2. Osteomyelitis progression: The patient's R foot ulcer/Osteomyelitis may progress, leading to further tissue damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Pericarditis or myositis: The patient's chest pain may be related to pericarditis or myositis, which can lead to cardiac complications if not properly managed.
4. Tachycardia-related complications: The patient's tachycardia may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure, if not properly managed.
5. Renal complications: The patient's bandemia may lead to renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, if not properly managed.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's hypothyroidism and chronic neuropathy may lead to neurological complications, such as cognitive impairment or seizures, if not properly managed.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   45 yo M with h/o spina bifida and peripheral neuropathy with chronic
   RLfoot ulcer, recently diagnosed L-spine lipoma and immunosupressed on
   Decadron x 5 weeks, p/w b/l LE cellulitis and CP several days, admitted
   for sepsis.
   # Sepsis: Pt presented to ED with tachycardia, elevated bands, and
   +Group G Streptococcal bacteremia c/w sepsis; no evidence of organ
   hypoperfusion. Source of infection most likely related to patient
   chronic RLE ulcer with resulting cellulitis in setting of
   immunosupression on Decadron for past 5 weeks and given recent changes
   in R foot. ?Fungemia. UCx-+ Klebsiella. HD: CVP about >10, MAP >65, yet
   pt continues to be tachycardic. Afebrile O/N. Lactates trending down.
   WBC elevated. +5.3 LOS balance
   - Appreciate Derm, ID, Plastics, Podiatry, Surgery recs
   - Continue Vancomycin, Zosyn and Clindamycin; Check Vanco trough before
   4^th dose to ensure range of 15-20.
   - Fluconazole 200mg PO q24hr
   - Continue IVF boluses as needed for HD stability, access currently
   with 2 PIV x 18 and x20g; CVL in R SCL
   - Follow-up all cultures
   - Decreased steroids to 3mg TID.
   - Warm pack to right arm
# R foot ulcer/Osteomyelitis: Chronic issue over past 7yrs. Ulcer at proximal po
rtion of 5th metatarsal base and portion of the cuboid. Well known to plastics/s
urgery. Secondary to neuopathy from spina bifida and tethered cord syndrome. CT
of foot yest reveals probable OM.
   - Appreciate Plastics/Podiatry inputs
   - Antibiotics as above
   - FXR today
   - daily wet to dry dressing changes
   - f/u wound culture/biopsy
   #HSV: Presents with hand and upper lip ulcerations in setting of
   immunosuppression. DFA + HSV1.
   -F/u viral cx
   -Acyclovir 400mg 5x/day x7days
   -Monitor BUN/Cr/UOP for renal changes
   #Odynophagia: Considering h/o oral thrush and current odynophagia,
   possible candidia esophagitis. Also considering HSV esophagitis
   considering patient has HSV + lesions on lip and lesion on hard/soft
   pallate. Ruled out of MI to date. Seen by ID.
   -          Fluconazole 200mg PO qday; Acyclovir 400mg 5x/day x7days.
   -          Will d/w GI and possibly obtain EGD.
   #Knee Pain: Pt reports having increased bil (L>R) knee pain with
   decreased ROM immunosuppression and bacteremia, ?septic arthritis;
   tapped yesterday, culture pending, minimal WBC.
   -F/u Culture results
   -Continue Abx regimen as above
   # Chest pain: Likely [**2-23**] pericarditis vs myositis.  With regards to
   pericarditis, etiology most likely infectious.   MI ruled out. EKG most
   consistent with diffuse process such as pericarditis. Bedside ECHO:
   normal LV fxn, LVEF>55%, mild MR, mod posterior pericardial effusion,
   no signs of tamponade. Formal ECHO not performed.
   - RO
ed MI by cardiac enzymes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Formal ECHO today
   - Cardiology recs if condition changes.
   - Ibuprofen scheduled for pericarditis (could also use indomethacine or
   colcicine)
   - Pain management with Morphine PRN, Percocet, Acetaminophen
   # Tachycardia: Likely [**2-23**] multiple etiologies including systemic
   inflammatory response/sepsis, pain, anxiety, and pericarditis, recent
   increase in levothyroxine.  No evidence of tamponade on bedside Echo in
   ED.  Ruled out of MI.  Tox screen neg.  Not on beta blocker so unlikely
   to be having rebound.  Does have h/o hypothyroidism, TSH low, T3/T4
   low/normal c/w subclinical hyperthyroidism.
   - IVF PRN
   - Ibuprofen for pericarditis
   - Morphine PRN, Acetaminophen, Percocet
   # Bandemia: Likely from cellulitis as above.  Other possible sources
   including urine, pleural effusion or pericardial effusion.
   - Follow-up urine/blood cultures &  Antibiotics as above
   #Transaminitis: Moderate elevation c/w possible infection or decreased
   perfusion related to sepsis or medication induced.
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   #Hypothyroidism: TSH <0.02. Free T4 (WNL) and T3 (low) c/w subclinical
   hyperthyroidism. Reports recent change in levothyroxine (175mcg) qday
   which could exacerbate tachycardia and changes in labs may not be
   apparent so close to change in dosage.
   -Clarify home doses of thyroid medication with PCP at some point during
   admission.
   -recheck TFTs if tachycardia continues
   # L-spine Lipoma: States to have been dx about 6 weeks prior.  Spoke
   with [**Doctor Last Name 1226**] (Neurology) at [**Hospital1 **] yesterday.  On decadron x 5-6 weeks
   for cord compression. Spinal cord decompression in [**Month (only) 3**] at [**Hospital1 2898**].
   - Weaned yest to 3mg TID given concern for diffuse infection
   - Hold stress dose steroids unless develops septic physiology
   # Neurogenic Bladder: Continue oxybutyin.  Foley catheter in place.
   # Acne: Back, anterior chest wall, forehead.  Likely [**2-23**] bacterial
   overgrowth since the decadron although could be fungal related.
   -          Appreciate derm consult
   -          Benzoyl Peroxide 10% gel; clindamycin topical 1% lotion [**Hospital1 7**]
   #Spina bifida/tethered cord syndrome: No new issues. Possible
   contributing to chronic bilateral LE neuropathy.
   -Monitor for changes in neuron status
   PPx: bowel regimen PRN, hold pneumboots, heparin SC
   FEN: IVF x 4L, replete PRN, clears
   Access: PIV x 2 (18,20). R SCL CVL
   Code Status:  FULL (confirmed on admission)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **], girlfriend, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2840**] (home) or [**0-0-**]
   (cell)
   Dispo: Call out to floor as HD stable.

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of spina bifida, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic right lower extremity (RLE) ulcer. He was recently diagnosed with a left-spine lipoma and has been taking Decadron for the past 5 weeks. He presented to the emergency department with tachycardia, elevated bands, and Group G Streptococcal bacteremia, consistent with sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU for management of sepsis and treatment of his underlying conditions.

The patient has several comorbidities, including chronic RLE ulcer, osteomyelitis, and immunosuppression, which have led to a complicated course of treatment. He has been treated with antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Zosyn, and Clindamycin, and has also received antifungal therapy with Fluconazole. He has been experiencing chest pain, which is thought to be related to pericarditis or myositis, and has undergone bedside echocardiography to rule out tamponade.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, including elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and inflammatory markers. His liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down, and his thyroid function tests (TFTs) show subclinical hyperthyroidism.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if he does not respond to treatment or if he develops resistance to antibiotics.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's chronic RLE ulcer and osteomyelitis may lead to further complications, including infection and potential amputation.
3. Pericarditis: The patient's chest pain and echocardiography results suggest pericarditis, which may require further treatment and monitoring.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's subclinical hyperthyroidism may worsen if he does not receive proper treatment and monitoring.
5. Neurogenic bladder: The patient's neurogenic bladder may lead to further complications, including urinary tract infections and kidney damage.
6. Acne: The patient's acne may worsen if he does not receive proper treatment and monitoring.
7. Tethered cord syndrome: The patient's tethered cord syndrome may lead to further complications, including neurogenic bladder and bowel dysfunction.

Given the patient's complex medical history and comorbidities, it is essential to monitor him closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.
